metadata.case_name: Kishore Chandra Singh Deo v. Legal Representatives of Radha Prasad Bhagat

facts.text: Mortgage deed Exhibit A dated 5th April 1923 executed by defendant in favour of Radha Prasad Bhagat for Rs. 1,25,000 on Bodogodo Zemindari, an impartible estate under Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904.

Deed recites Rs. 12,500 advanced via promissory note Exhibit J dated 30th March 1923, balance Rs. 1,12,500 paid in cash, borrowed for marriage of defendant's second daughter with eldest son of Rajah of Talcher.
Rs. 1,12,500 paid on 14th April 1923 to Mr. Henry Tapp, defendant's manager, on defendant's authority, after mortgage registered on 10th April 1923.
Defendant made payments in 1926 and 1927 aggregating Rs. 42,000 towards mortgage.
Mortgagee Radha Prasad Bhagat died on 18th November 1933; legal representatives filed suit in 1935 (Original Suit No. 11 of 1935) for balance due by sale of property.
Subordinate Judge of Berhampore decreed for plaintiffs on 23rd November 1936: no consideration for Exhibit J (salami), but Rs. 1,12,500 paid to Tapp authorised, bond duly attested and registered.
High Court of Patna in First Appeals Nos. 10 and 11 of 1939 on 22nd December 1942: concurred on payment to Tapp authorised, attested/registered ok, but held Exhibit J supported by consideration.
Power-of-attorney Exhibit B executed by defendant before Registrar at residence of Chief of Hindol at Cuttack; defendant temporarily residing there for a week prior.
Exhibit B presented by P. Sundaram, but actually for authentication at residence; Registrar examined defendant, satisfied voluntary execution, authenticated under s.33 Registration Act.
Defendant's son studying at Cuttack, residing in Chief of Hindol's house; defendant at Cuttack to complete loan negotiations, borrowed Rs.12,500 under Exhibit J there.
Defendant died while appeals pending; legal representatives prosecuting.
Trial court found mortgage not binding on estate under s.4 Madras Impartible Estates Act; High Court discharged finding, left open for other proceedings.

legal_issues.text: Whether mortgage Exhibit A supported by consideration to full extent of Rs.1,25,000.
Whether mortgage bond duly attested and validly registered.
Whether power-of-attorney Exhibit B validly authenticated under ss.32 and 33 Registration Act: residence at Cuttack, presentation by Sundaram, bodily infirmity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mortgage supported by consideration only to extent of Rs.25,000; discharged by payments of Rs.42,000 in 1926-1927.
Mortgage bond not duly attested or validly registered, hence void.
Power Exhibit B invalid: defendant not residing at Cuttack (permanent residence Bodogodo, stayed casually at brother-in-law's house); Registrar at Cuttack no jurisdiction under s.33(1)(a).
Exhibit B presented for registration by Sundaram (personal assistant, not authorised under s.32), so authentication void.
No bodily infirmity; authentication at residence under proviso s.33(1) bad.

respondent_arguments.text: Rs.1,12,500 paid to Mr. Tapp on defendant's authority after registration.
Exhibit J (promissory note Rs.12,500) supported by consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Courts below found mortgage supported by consideration (Rs.12,500 via Exhibit J, Rs.1,12,500 to Tapp authorised); duly attested.
court_reasoning.key_observation: On consideration of evidence, mortgage bond supported by consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Temporary residence at Cuttack sufficient under s.33(1)(a); defendant resided there a week, for loan negotiations, son's studies; Registrar's endorsement confirms residence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Resides' includes temporary residence; ample materials support finding.

court_reasoning.text: Exhibit B not presented for registration but for authentication; endorsement of presentation a mistake (per rules, separate for authentication; only authentication charges collected); Registrar examined at residence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.32 applies to registration, not mere authentication under s.33.

court_reasoning.text: Registrar's decision on bodily infirmity procedural, within jurisdiction; even if erroneous, does not invalidate; defendant re-signed before Registrar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguish defects in procedure from lack of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Mortgage validly supported by consideration, duly attested and registered; power-of-attorney Exhibit B validly authenticated.
Presentation by unauthorised person for registration does not invalidate subsequent authentication under s.33 at principal's residence.
Registrar's authentication under proviso s.33(1) valid even if no infirmity, as jurisdictional fact not challengeable collaterally.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jambu Prasad v. Muhammad Aftar Ali Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Sections 32 and 33 imperative; unauthorised presentation makes registration void.
Supports Jambu Prasad on imperative nature of ss.32,33.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Resides' in s.33 includes temporary residence; Registrar's endorsement evidence of residence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Unauthorised presentation for registration cured by subsequent registration/authentication at residence under s.33.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguish procedural defects from lack of jurisdiction; Registrar's mistake on infirmity does not invalidate.
Examples of lack of jurisdiction (e.g., unauthorised presenter, territorial).

statutes_cited.name: Registration Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs presentation and authentication of power-of-attorney for registration of mortgage; requirements mandatory but temporary residence sufficient, procedural errors do not void if jurisdiction exists.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904
statutes_cited.relevance: Whether mortgage binding on estate; issue left open by High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed upholding High Court decree enforcing mortgage; question of binding on impartible estate left open for other proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; mortgage decree stands.

key_quotes.text: The expression 'resides', as used in section 33, is not defined in the statute but there is no reason for assuming that it contemplates only permanent residence and excludes temporary residence.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is important to distinguish between defects in the procedure of the Registrar and lack of jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why infirmity finding not challengeable.

key_quotes.text: The terms of sections 32 and 33 of Act III of 1877 are imperative, and that a presentation of a document for registration by an agent who has not been duly authorized in accordance with those sections, does not give to the Registering Officer the indispensable foundation of his authority to register the document.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites Jambu Prasad on mandatory nature but distinguishes application.
